description.narrative:
Insatsen som föreslås av Development Initiatives (DI) syftar till att bidra till en förbättrad faktabas inom området humanitärt bistånd genom stöd till produktion av DIs årsrapport om humanitära finansiella flöden; flaggskeppsrapporten "Global Humanitarian Assistance Report (GHA rapport 2016)". Aktivitetsperioden är januari-augusti 2016 (åtta månader). Efter återkoppling från Sida att flerårigt kärnstöd inte längre är möjligt har DI inkommit med ett förslag till samarbete som är inriktat på en specifik produkt som ska levereras under 2016 - GHA rapporten.
DI har producerat den årliga GHA rapporten sedan 2000 för ändamålet att ge en objektiv, oberoende och förbättrad faktabas om finansiering av humanitära kriser. DI har totalt producerat elva GHA rapporter. Det är den enda organisation som gör detta och har med tiden utvecklat en värderad och erkänd roll i sektorn. En oberoende utvärdering daterad 2015-04-17 (Barnaby Willitts-King) konstaterar att GHA rapporten är en "go-to resurs" som erbjuder en "gyllene standard" när det gäller tillgänglig rapportering och presentation av humanitär finansieringsdata. Feedback indikerar att rapporten används av ett stort antal intressenter inklusive statliga givare, multilaterala organ, Röda korset, frivilligorganisationer, analytiker och media som en resurs för beslutsfattande, briefing, analys och opinionsbildning. GHA rapporten citeras i processer inför det humanitära toppmötet 2016 (WHS) samt av högnivåpanelen för humanitär finansiering.

The intervention aims to contribute to improving the evidence base in the field of humanitarian aid by supporting the production of DI's Annual Report on humanitarian financial flows; – the flagship "Global Humanitarian Assistance Report (the GHA 2016 report)". Upon feedback from Sida that a commitment to multi-year core programme funding is not currently possible, the proposal focuses on a specific project to be delivered in 2016 - the GHA report. The activity period is January to August 2016 (eight months).
Development Initiatives has been producing the annual GHA Report since 2000 in order to provide an objective, independent and rigorous evidence base on financing for humanitarian crises. DI has in total produced eleven GHA reports. It is the only resource that does this and has developed a valued and recognised role in the sector. The independent evaluation in 2015 found that “GHA’s annual report is a ‘go-to resource’ that offers the ‘gold standard’ in terms of accessible reporting and presentation of humanitarian financing data.” Feedback indicates that the report is used by a wide range of stakeholders including government donors, multi-lateral agencies, Red Cross, NGOs, analysts and media as a resource for decision-making, briefing, analysis and advocacy. It has been cited in the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) processes (including the synthesis reporti) as well as by the High Level Panel (HLP) on Humanitarian Financing.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The contribution refers to ear-marked simplified support to Development Initiatives’ core deliverable Global Humanitarian Assistance (GHA) Report 2016 and 2017, with the objective to provide a comprehensive overview, and give an unbiased, independent, and improved evidence base within humanitarian crisis financing. Since the reports were the main outputs of DI’s larger GHA Programme Phase III, the submitted narrative report contained various projects which Sida did not directly fund, yet became important chapters of the actual report. Sida sees the added value of the report from its analysis of topics that support the reform of needs-based crisis financing. For example, the report’s analysis on the links between poverty and crisis, risks and resources contributes to efforts to bridge the humanitarian-development divide in line with the sustainable development goals. Equally, this report supports official processes established to monitor progress and sustain political momentum of the Grand Bargain (GB) by evaluating progress against GB’s commitment areas, such as transparency, localisation, earmarking and cash. In 2017 the report included an assessment on wider crisis financing mechanisms and early action with reference to the El Niño events in East Africa. The amount of reports downloaded in 2017 (1,114 downloads from DI’s and GHA's Websites) indicate that the GHA report has reached a wider audience, as compared to 2016 and 2015, with 1,000 and 659 downloads, respectively. Similarly, the rise in the number of visits to the report page from 788 in 2015 to 1,108 in 2016 to 1,954 in 2017. One reason for the increase could be that this was the first year DI “published the report solely on the DI website, and indicates that the move has positively impacted on people engaging with the report.” The most popular content in terms of number of downloads were: Donors; People; Crisis Financing; Effectiveness; Location; and, Timing. Furthermore, DI has been able to report on their results throughout the period through three telephone meetings with Sida with minutes recorded in Dox (archive number 021953/18). These separate work streams included in the GHA report is also relevant regarding Sida’s steering towards a multi-year programme support.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
